1/5 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I‚Äôd hear him talk about a number called degree days, which comes from a formula that includes the mean monthly temperature.
2/5 The number of degree days for the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas the company should have on hand to sell next March.
3/5 But they‚Äôd need an extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than other recent years. Each March has its own unpredictable degree day total, when all is said and done.
4/5 Our local natural gas company stored gas reserves in a porous layer of rock beneath the north side of the metro area. Buy it cheap in the summer, pump it underground, and pump it out later when it's needed.
5/5 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that‚Äôs thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that‚Äôs thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.
